title: HTTP, DNS, and Request/Response
content:
Module 1, Lesson 1: The Web's DNA — HTTP, DNS, and Request/Response

Introduction

Think of the internet as a massive city. DNS (Domain Name System) is the phone book — you don't memorise everyone's address; you look up "Google" and it translates to 142.250.80.46. When you type a URL, your browser is like a tourist asking for directions.

HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the language spoken between your browser (the client) and the server. You send a polite REQUEST: "GET me the homepage, please." The server responds with a RESPONSE: "Here's your HTML. Status: 200 OK!"

Key Concepts

HTTP Methods

Request methods are like ordering at a drive-thru. GET means "show me the menu" (retrieve data). POST is "here's my order" (send data). PUT updates your order, DELETE cancels it.

Status Codes

Status codes are the server's mood: 200s are happy ("OK!"), 300s are indecisive ("Try over there"), 400s blame you ("Bad Request"), and 500s blame themselves ("Internal Server Error").

Headers and Body

Headers carry metadata: cookies (your VIP pass), content-type (is this JSON or HTML?), and authorisation tokens. The body is the actual payload — the data you're sending or receiving.

Summary

Mastering HTTP isn't just about memorising codes; it's about understanding the conversation. Every click, every form submission, every API call is a request-response tango. When you grasp this flow, debugging becomes intuitive.

quiz.question: What does DNS stand for and what is its primary function?
options: Domain Network System — manages network traffic
Domain Name System — translates domain names to IP addresses
Digital Name Service — encrypts domain requests
Data Navigation System — routes packets efficiently
